awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH:  Mechanisms for the decline of leaf hydraulic conductance with dehydration, and plant and environment level impacts
awd_abstract_narration: In this project,the mechanisms and consequences of a major plant response will be determined that is increasingly recognized to play a central role in processes at cell, tissue and whole-plant level - the vulnerability of the leaf water transport (hydraulic) system to dehydration.  Equally, the implications of leaf water transport for stomatal control and urban forest-level transpiration, a major component of city water use, will be clarified.  For diverse urban trees in Los Angeles, the project will combine new experimental and nano-microscopy techniques with modeling to determine the relative roles in the dynamics of leaf hydraulic conductance (Kleaf) of mechanisms including air blockage within the leaf veins, cell collapse, and changes in the activity of membrane proteins (aquaporins).  Second, the project will study the role of Kleaf in the determination of the stomatal response to atmospheric drought.  A novel computer simulation model of the water transport and gas exchange systems will be developed, to be parameterized with data from experiments and from anatomical analyses.  This model will predict the effect of xylem anatomy and its dynamics during transpiration or drought on the responses of stomata.  The project will test and refine this model against experimental measurements of gas exchange responses for the urban trees.  The third objective is to combine the measurements and model with additional functional trait data to predict tree water use and water use efficiency, and to test these predictions with sapflow and growth measurements for urban trees.  Overall,this research will break new scientific ground in clarifying the dynamics of plant water transport, and improving prediction of urban forest water use, especially critical for conservation of water resources.  The broader educational impacts include collaborative data collection within a mentoring program for under-represented undergraduates in research, to improve participation and appreciation of urban ecophysiology and ecology.

por.por_cntn:
In this Collaborative Research we provided key resolution of the mechanisms and consequences of a major plant response that is increasingly recognized to play a central role in processes at cell, tissue and whole-plant level—the vulnerability of the leaf hydraulic system to dehydration. This process is important in determining plant growth and its response to drought and scales up to influencing the productivity of ecosystems and their feedback on climate. We showed how the decline of leaf hydraulic conductance (Kleaf) during leaf dehydration can thus cause stomatal closure, reducing photosynthesis, and drive diurnal and seasonal cycles of gas exchange and water use as well as declines during drought. We collected novel physiological data for over 60 urban tree species of California, created and tested models for leaf and whole plant function, developed new technology for estimating plant drought tolerance worldwide, and showed the influence of leaf design on plant evolution and ecological distributions. Our work led to breakthrough understanding of plant function at the scale of cells, whole plants and ecosystems—we showed that declines in Kleaf correspond to cell shrinkage and/or to changes in membrane permeability rather than to embolism in the veins as previously thought, and that the declines in Kleaf will reduce function of the whole plant. Scaling up to the plot and municipal level, we showed that urban tree transpiration makes a smaller contribution to urban evapotranspiration than previously assumed, given the dominant role of turfgrass. The project led to contributions and discoveries on a wide range of topics and over 30 publications in high impact journals, with more in development. These topics include the determination of the tree water use in urban species, the physics of water movement within leaves, the processes that unfold in plant cells and tissues during drought, what determines drought tolerance in different plant species and ecosystems, the influence of climate on ecosystems worldwide, and the contribution of plants to the determination of climate. New datasets have been generated on leaf and plant drought tolerance, gas exchange, sap flow, and venation systems, which can contribute to the parameterization of models of plant function and the determination of plant climate and which will be shared worldwide via online resources. More than 5 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and more than 40 undergraduate and high school students gained mentoring and training on cutting edge physiological techniques.


Last Modified: 05/27/2016
Modified by: Lawren Sack
